element_texts.text: Completed
Dear Mother, I wish I could see you and May. We went to the lake on the 4 and had a nice time and made
Completed

Elyria July 15 1899
Dear Mother
I should like to see you very much
We have got our bureau it has got [?] a little drawers and three big drawers it cost fifteen dollers (sic) it is made of curly mapple (sic) I caught a rabbit he did eat chickweed like everything But one day I was holding him in my hand and he got away from me. We sold a boushel (sic) of peas to Mister Williams. And morning I carried a basket full of peas to uncle Eliab and one basket of peas to uncle Doctor. Wilder and I have helped Father's haying. We picked twenty [?] of currants and got ten cents apeice (sic) Father think he is going to the lake again
Your loving
Son
Charlie Metcalf
Completed

Lawrence, Kan., Dec 9 1884
Dear Father
Your letters of the Fifth & Sixth and telegram of seventh received also telegram from Uncle Eliab in answer to one from Wilder
Hope to get another letter to day and hear how Ralph is. Am almost inclined to start back this P.M. anyway picking up Ethel on the way if she has not already gone. I should have stayed there when I was there. Has Bertha come back? If I could only write a letter I would try to do so now, but don't know how.
I can only say that she seemed to be just as much mother to me as she was to her own boys.
Chas
Completed

Elyria, Ohio,
Feb. 9, 1866.
Dear father,
I miss you very much. I want to See you. It snowed yesterday. Mary is hear (sic) She expects to stay here till you are home, Mary is taking care of John now. Its noon now. We have just got done dinner. I was ten at School this forenoon. The first bell is ringing now. I will stop now and when I get home from
Completed

School I will write Some more I have been ten this afternoon too. We have just got done supper now. We are all just playing Hydensite
Mother is just undressing John.
Your loving
Son Charley.
Completed

Lawrence, Kansas, Aug 3-1930
Dear Marion:-
Your letter from Point Chautauqua post-marked July 31, but not dated is here Saturday- Its been terribly hot today with a hot wind blowing. The corn is mostly plum gone & beyond all help - no matter how much it rains. The thermometer goes over 100 every day. Maybe we can live thro the winter but more likely we will all dry up & blow away - Any way its getting pretty serious - I'm glad you folks have found a cool place but Kansas is not the only hot place. As you know if you see the papers - you say you had a letter from Mary Stanley & Gammon - is that it?- or what is that last name? Who is she & where is she? When you face the lake are you facing in what direction? Is the lake longest east-& west - and are you at which end of the lake or on the side of it somewhere? Maybe you have told me this some time before - Did you go thro to Westfield with out change? Are John Carrie in Washington now? Does Nette come direct to you from N.Y. or does she land where? and come to Chautauqua later? I went into the P.O. Thursday or maybe Friday morning and stood there waiting for the
Completed

mail and a man came in with a boy 6 or 8 years old. He said the boy was leaving that morning for Boston or Wellesley. His father - a professor of somoething I take it was going there & would be much of the time in the Wellesley College library. My mail came and his turn at the P.O. window came & I had not no further words with him - but Ive known the man a long time and know he has a daughter but did no know if she had children or the name or her now - The boy was evidently his grandson. The man has a son - a graduate of West Point who is an engineer - I think - in the regular Army. I have not heard anything about the daughter for some time think I had heard she was married but did not know what her name is or what her husband does. The automobile is a great institution - They are here on the street every day from all over everywhere. [?} got a card from John from Munich dated 7117-30 with picture of the Passion Play Theatre. A ride along the lake shore from Cleveland to Lorraine now must be quite unlike a ride from Cleveland to Lorain 50 or 60 yrs ago say before people began to find out there was a lake there and before the Auto - Almost like a [?] up town all the way?
Chas R.M
Completed

Frankfort, Mich Aug 15, 1930
Dear General Metcalf:
I read of the death of Charles the other day in the Journal World and am writing to express and extend my sympathy to you in this break (the first I believe) in your immediate family circle.
I shall miss him. Quiet, extremely quiet as he was, he filled a place in my life. He was never absent from public worship and he was regular as a clock in my Sunday School
class. He stood for something. One knew that up here - the Riggs girls have been telling me about him and his activity in Christian Endeavor in the old days.
Back home again. It feels good to be home. I had a wonderful, wonderful trip. Germany impressed me more than any other land I visited. I am anxious to tell you all about it.
Sincerely,
Alfred W. Green
Completed

Sheet 1
My Memories of my brother Charlie
The first I remember Charlie was on my 5th birthday. I had just received, as I have always thought, my first pair of trousers. I was walking from the house down the narrow walk toward the barn and as I passed Charlie who was working in the woodshed he said "Don't wet them."
I remember very plainly the day the family picture was taken. This was sometime before 1889 probably around 1887. Someone, it seems to me it was Harl had to go to the mill to get Charlie to come to the photograph gallery. I also remember several times in the north bed room of the old house, sleeping with Charlie and feeling he was crowding me off the bed.
When I went to Lawrence I roomed the first year with him at Wilder's and I boarded with Wilder. I mowed the lawn and did a few odd jobs and thought I was earning my board but found Marian sent Wilder $2,50 a week for my board. Charlie always left the house very early in the morning and came in fairly late at night so I didn't really get acquainted with him until the next year when we moved to Mrs Eldridge's house about a block away still on Rhode Island Street. Charlie paid the room rent but really wasn't in the room over 7 or 8 hours a day staying in the office nights. I studied in the office frequently and when I suggested we go home, Charlie would say "go home when you can't go somewhere else" and before going home he asked me to go out and walk with him. During those long walks we surely covered the town but there was very little said. That year I don't remember what breakfast, if any, either of us ate but we did get one big meal a day at Epp's restaurant costing by means of a $3.00 meal ticket just 16 2/3 cents a meal. If there was any bread left on the plate Charlie put it in his pocket and for supper we ate it with peanuts, apples and blackened bananas in the office. During the evening very frequently some hard up looking man would come in for a loan. After thoroughly questioning him he usually went away jingling
Completed

a little money in his pocket. It wasn't always for money loan he they came in. I have seen several come in to hand Charlie a payment either in full or partial, probably principally to keep his audit good. I would make a guess, tho, that most of the pages in his account book showed the money going out much more often and larger than the money coming in. I often have wished that his account book had been saved. It would be very interesting. There were several pages of investments in oil stock which seldom had given a return. He told me of several which he still thought would amount to something. That was a time when Eastern Kansas was booming with gas and oil discoveries and such towns as Iola were bringing in smelters and other factories which came to enjoy cheap gas fuel. The prospects for gas and oil even went out into Western Kansas where Charlie was part owner of quite a little acreage only to be lost when hard times came.
I am afraid Charlie always had a feeling he had worked a lot without being recompensed properly like his many years in the flour mill, and I know he felt during many of his last years at Lawrence that he was taken advantage of. I don't know for sure, but I think there were many months when the business didn't leave enough for his small salary and he went without even tho Wilder had enough to support his riding horse and a good living. Sometimes, but not often, I heard him speak quite bitterly.'
I think maybe the family owed him more than most of us know and I suppose probably I owed him more than the others as I lived in his room for 4 years and some of the time he paid for many of my meals.
When I came home one night, Sept. 14, 1903 and told him I had just "popped the question to Clara" the only remark I got from him was "Has she got good teeth?" She did have and still has, which is more than I can say about her husband. I think Charlie got to like Clara very much as when we lived in Topeka some 6 months, he very frequently came up for Sunday to see us.
During my last year at KU, I boarded at what was called The Que Vera Club and my savings from the summer's work
Completed

Sheet 2
were insufficient to pay my expenses. I borrowed in all about $350 from Charlie secured by my first $1000 insurance policy, an endorsement policy with Northwestern Mutual.
On graduation I went to work as a draftsman for the Illinois Steel Co. in Chicago. I continued to live on one meal a day with a glass of milk and breakfast food for breakfast and a couple of sweet rolls for supper, eating a hearty dinner at a laborer's boarding house near the steel plant at 35 cents a meal. My main idea in life was to pay back Charlie that $350 and then save a little to get married onl. I found an old account book of mine recently that showed my regular payments to him. It took a little over three months at $50 a month but not many more months at $75 and travelling expenses when I went to Beaumont Texas in September.
I heard from Charlie regularly probably every week while I was in Texas and often I went to Montana. He never wrote much but always sent many clippings from the Lawrence paper.
Charlie, as we all know, never went to College. I never knew why not, but I'm ready to bet he know more of worth while knowledge than most of his brothers and sisters who had the advantage of a college education. He was very well read and kept thoroughly abreast of the times.
I don't believe he ever joined a church but he was a regular attendant at the Congregational Church in Lawrence and while I was there, at least, attended old Cap't Haskell's Men's Sunday School class every Sunday even during the year I was persuaded to teach a class of 11 or 12 year old girls. Very frequently also we attended the Midweek prayer meeting. I suppose I was brought up to believe that it was necessary to belong to a church to be a Christian but I learned different those years with Charlie. I'll stake his chances for a happy future life against that of any onen else's.
Completed

I have been a member of some eight different churches Congregational & Presbyterian, scattered from Elyria to Texas and Seattle Washington and have been a regular attendant at several others but I'll take my hat off to Charlies' kind of Christianity any day.
Charlie used to come home for a visit nearly every year. One time just after we had moved to East [?} house he bawled Marian out because she had brought back from Battle Creek Mich. the notion that breakfasts were superflous. He said "Feed the Kids" When he came home there was no use trying to meet the train. He always jumped off at the last crossing and would beat the meeters home.
I remember when but a small lad he made fun of the way I held my bread & butter. He rolled his hands together and asked why I didn't do that to the bread.
Completed

The Sleigh ride.
I went sleigh riding one bright sunny afternoon, with a company of schoolmates. We went in a large sleigh, drawn by two horses. The sleighing was very good. It was not very cold, and I had my overcoat and scarf on, and was very comfortable. We went over the ground pretty fast, out to the neighboring town of Ridgeville, where we had a fine time. Their (sic) was quite a lot of snow on the ground. The bushes and streams were all frozen, and looked very nice. In the summer, the trees would be covered with green leaves, and the streams flowing along very fast. We met a great many sleigh loads going to town. I enjoyed myself very much, but was glad to get home again.
C.R. Metcalf
